bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 6, 1906

div1.p: Gorgas writes about the management of the Sanitary Department. He comments on his relationship with his superior officers in the government.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 6, 1906

opener.dateline:
ISTHMIAN CANAL ZONE
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
____
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER
ANCON, C. Z.
June 6th 1906.

div1.p:
Yours of the 21st of May, received.
I wrote you a long & confedential
letter I think about April 21st,
though I cannot be certain.

Surely though in time for you to
have received it by May 21st,
I stamped it & marked it person-
al, I will rewrite it if I do not
hear from you soon, though there
was a good deal in it that I
would not like to go astray

Tell Mrs. Kean that Mrs. Gorgas'
address is “20 Central Park West
N. Y. City” She expects to sail
for Panama about the 18th,
2
If I do not hear from you in a
mail or two I will write again but
as that will have to be a very long
letter I do not want to waste too
much sweetness on this one.

Every thing lovely down here
& the Sanitary Department on top.
Shouts did me the “amends honorable”
when he was here. Took me out for
a drive & told me that he hoped to
see at the end of a year to see the other de-
partments as well organized &
as efficient as the Sanitary Depart-
ment now was. Pretty good
for a man who just a year
ago asked to have me relieved
for inefficiency. Did I ever
tell you that I was told by a
man who said that he knew the
fools that when the Secretary
came back from that interview
3
with Wallace he & Shouts had gone to
the president by appointment & recom-
mended that I be relieved down
here.

Magoon & I are still cooing though
he of course knows that I have
read Tafts evidence.

I received the book from Dr. Mood-
ward & acknowlidged.

With kindest regards to you & yours
I remain
